The forecast of heat consumption on the consumer side is a crucial first step towards an optimal energy supply. However, due to the non-linearity and non-stationarity of heat consumption data, predicting the thermal energy demand of district energy systems (DES) remains challenging. In this work, we propose a forecasting framework for thermal energy consumption within a district heating system (DHS) based on kernel Support Vector Regression (kSVR) using real-world smart meter data. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is employed to find the optimal hyper-parameters for the kSVR model, which leads to the superiority of the proposed method when compared to a state-of-the-art ARIMA model. The average Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) is reduced to 2.07% and 2.64% for individual meter-specific forecasting and societal consumption forecasting, respectively.

Introduction
According to the United Nations Environment Program, cities are a key contributor to climate change, as urban areas are responsible for 75% of global CO2 emissions. One effective way to combat climate change is through the use of district energy systems (DES), which require demand-driven thermal energy supply based on real consumption. However, utilities tend to over-supply the DES network, as the security of the energy supply must be ensured, and the accumulated energy consumption acquired by the consumer side installation of smart meters is solely used for billing purposes. Hence, the behavior of the end-consumer remains largely unknown for the utilities while operating the DES network. Consequently, an accurate forecast of thermal energy demand is the logical first step towards an optimized energy supply of the entire network.

The focus of our work is on the energy demand forecast of district heating systems (DHS), which is the majority of the installed DES networks worldwide. Although statistical forecast methods, such as AR, ARIMA, or SARIMA models, have demonstrated promising results, the prediction accuracy of energy load is limited due to the non-linearity in the underlying time series. Recently, a model using artificial neural networks (ANN) has been proposed to address the non-linearity present in heat consumption/load data. However, the training of ANN is often challenging, as it has a tendency to be trapped in local optima. Deeper models like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) have the capability to model the underlying trend, seasonality, residuals, and external factors. However, the training of such models requires a large amount of data, which is not available for the vast majority of utilities.

Traditional machine learning methods, such as Support Vector Regression (SVR), which is equipped with the inherent capability to deal with non-linearity, present a compromise. SVR-based methods have demonstrated their superiority to other machine learning models for heat load prediction. As the performance and usability of SVR are greatly affected by the choice of model hyper-parameters, evolutionary algorithms such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) are employed to determine the optimal hyper-parameters automatically. Previously, PSO-SVR has been proposed for load prediction of a DHS based on daily heat load data during the heating season acquired from the production plant, demonstrating promising results.

Our main contributions are: (1) a machine learning-based forecast framework enables the use of accumulated heat consumption data acquired with smart meters installed on the end-consumer side; (2) the formulation of a PSO-kSVR model that has the inherent capability to deal with the non-linearity of the underlying data; and (3) to the best of our knowledge, exploring the use of PSO-SVR and accumulated heat consumption for the forecast of energy load with real-world smart meter data on the household level for the first time.

Accumulated Consumption Data and Data Analysis
The smart meter data used in this work is provided by a Danish utility with an hourly temporal resolution. It is a small-sized municipality with 3808 consumers. As the smart meters are installed one after the other instead of all at once, the time period of the raw data spans from 6 to 12 months. Additionally, publicly available meteorological data of the same municipality at the same time interval are utilized to incorporate the weather conditions. Stationarity tests and decomposition methods are applied to analyze the data property. The accumulated energy consumption over a year is non-linear and non-stationary, as shown in Figure 1(a). However, it shows a linear trend.
